intro: Brachionidium syme-morrisii, commonly known as the Syme-Morris' water flea, is a small, free-living marine copepod belonging to the family Calanidae. It is characterized by its elongated, translucent body and complex appendages used for swimming and feeding. This species is typically found in coastal waters and estuaries, where it plays a role in the pelagic food web. Its life cycle includes several developmental stages, including nauplius and copepodite stages, before reaching maturity. Due to its small size and ecological significance, it is often used as an indicator species for water quality and ecosystem health.
